item.title: By: Andrew Whitacre
item.dc:creator: Andrew Whitacre
item.description:
Turns out, readers can be their own worst super villain, for as we learned today, Anonymous created a replica of the Times online Opinion page and had "Bill Keller" express complete, rather than his actual conflicted, support of WikiLeaks: http://www.opinion-nytimes.com/2012/07/29/opinion/keller-a-post-postscript.html They followed it with a similar hoax statement from PayPal: http://www.thepaypalblog.co/2012/07/statement-on-nytimes.html
Some really important journalism ethics people fell for it, including our friend Dan Gillmor and the more prominent Glen Greenwald.
Now, there certainly was some cleverness: the Keller piece lifted text Keller had actually written in the past. But are we really still at the point that "opinion-nytimes.com" and "thepaypalblog.co" don't give it away?

Dan, if you really really want to destroy a newspaper, the formula is very complex and top secret but I'll share it with you just this once. You ready? Here it is:
Retain the current management team. Do business as usual. Repeat.
